elements.text: Pkg shouldn't be vulnerable to this, since it's matching on UUID and not name, right?

text: The gist of it is that some package managers, when given a package name, by default look in "internal" repos first, then also check the "public" repos and install whichever returns a higher version number. For this attack to be successful in Pkg, the impersonator would have to also know the UUID of the internal package and register a package in General with both the same name and the same UUID.

For this attack to be successful in Pkg, the impersonator would have to also know the UUID of the internal package and register a package in General with both the same name and the same UUID.

text: So I guess the correct approach for corporate installs is to mirror General and don't resolve the public registry at all?
